sectionTitle: Anekāntavād III: The Five Samvāy (Causal Factors)

tabs.caption: Get started with the fundamental concepts of Jain causality and the principle of Anekāntavād.

items.header: Jain View of the Universe vs. Other Beliefs
items.content: Jain philosophy posits that the universe is eternal and uncreated. It operates according to natural laws and is composed of six basic, indestructible substances: Jīvāstikāy (Soul), Pudgalāstikāy (Material atoms), Dharmāstikāy (Medium of motion), Adharmāstikāy (Medium of rest), Ākāshāstikāy (Space), and Kāl (Time). This contrasts with beliefs that a divine being created and manages the universe. In Jainism, every individual experiences the results of their own Karma.

Samvāy is the name for the collective group of five distinct causal factors that function simultaneously to bring about any event or situation in the universe. No action can take place without these five causes being present and interacting. The principle of Anekāntavād (multiplicity of viewpoints) teaches us to consider all five factors rather than isolating just one as the sole cause.

tabs.caption: Explore the hierarchical relationship of the Five Causal Factors.

tabData.title: The Five Samvāy (Causal Factors)
tabData.description: A visual breakdown of Samvāy, the five simultaneous causes that collectively explain the occurrence of any event in Jain philosophy.

nodes.description: The group of five causal factors that must operate simultaneously for any action or reaction to occur.
Time. It provides sequence and maturity to events. The fruits of karma manifest at a specific time, not immediately.
Nature of a Substance. The inherent, unchangeable quality of an object or being. For example, a dog barks due to its nature.
Destiny or Fate. Certain events that are predetermined and unalterable, such as the aging process.
External Circumstances or Karma. An apparent or catalytic cause. It can be external (like a teacher's guidance) or internal (one's own past Karma).
Self-Effort or Free Will. The special place of individual effort and initiative, which is crucial for spiritual progress and overcoming Karma.

cards.back: The collective group of five simultaneous causal factors.
Time; the factor that gives sequence and determines when events occur.
Nature of a Substance; the inherent and unchangeable quality of something.
Destiny or Fate; predetermined and unalterable events.
External Circumstances or Karma; a catalytic or apparent cause.
Self-Effort or Free Will; individual initiative, crucial for spiritual progress.

cards.back: A lemon tree cannot grow mangoes; thorns are inherently sharp.

cards.front: What is an example of Niyati?
cards.back: The aging process, which cannot be prevented despite all efforts.

cards.front: What are the two types of Nimitta?

tabData.title: In-Depth Look at Each Causal Factor

items.content: Kāl acts as the controlling principle of sequence. Just as a seed needs time to grow into a tree and bear fruit, the effects of our Karma require time to manifest. One cannot expect results the moment an action is performed. Understanding the role of time teaches patience and prevents disappointment from unrealistic expectations.

Every substance has an inherent nature that dictates its properties and effects. Why are thorns sharp? Why do flowers have beautiful colors? This is due to their Svabhāv. Nothing can generate an effect that goes against its fundamental nature, even if all other factors like time and effort are present. You cannot grow mangoes on a lemon tree.

Niyati refers to events that are predetermined and unalterable. These are things beyond our control, no matter how much effort we apply. The most universal example is the aging process. While we control many aspects of our lives, acknowledging Niyati helps us accept the things we cannot change. In Jain terminology, this is linked to unalterable Karma (Niyat Nikachit Karma).

Nimitta is an apparent or catalytic cause. It can be external, such as the guidance of a Guru, a helpful object, or a specific event. It can also be internal, which is one's own past Karma. For example, two twins born to the same mother may have vastly different lives; Jainism attributes this to their individual internal Nimitta (Karma).

Jain philosophy places immense emphasis on Purushārth. It is the individual effort and initiative that drives progress. Human civilization has advanced solely through Purushārth. Critically, it is only human effort that can wage war against Karma, destroy it, and lead the soul to liberation (Siddha-shilā). Relying solely on other factors leads to indolence and failure.

tabs.caption: Learn how understanding Samvāy can enhance spiritual progress and dissolve ego.

items.content: The theory of Anekāntavād warns against the illusion of focusing on a single cause. To say 'time is everything' or 'it's all destiny' is a wrong view. The right view acknowledges that all five factors contribute to every outcome. While all are present, their level of importance can vary; for a specific effect, one factor may be principal while the others are subordinate.

items.header: A Tool for Humility and Responsibility
items.content:
For spiritual growth, one should reflect on the causes in a way that minimizes vice and ego. The suggested reflection is:
• If the result is positive: 'My success was due to the help from others (external Nimitta).' This cultivates humility.
• If the result is negative: 'My failure was due to my past Karma (internal Nimitta), destiny (Niyati), or my effort was inadequate (Purushārth).' This promotes self-responsibility and prevents blaming others.

Progress from the lowest state of ignorance (1st Gunasthān) to higher spiritual states requires Purushārth (self-effort). We can actively change two of the five causes: our Purushārth and our surrounding environment (Nimitta). By applying effort and choosing a proper environment, the effects of negative Karma are reduced, and the soul's purity increases, leading towards liberation.
